question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What award did Jonathan Leo Fairbanks receive after 2018?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
"The Art of Legacy: Jonathan Leo Fairbanks' Enduring Impact on American Crafts"

In the world of American crafts, few names resonate as profoundly as Jonathan Leo Fairbanks. As an artist, curator, and champion of the crafts, Fairbanks has left an indelible mark on the industry. Among his many accolades, one distinction stands out: his receipt of the prestigious Fellow of the American Craft Council award. This honor, bestowed upon individuals who have made outstanding contributions to the crafts in America, is a testament to Fairbanks' tireless dedication and innovative spirit. Born in 1950, Fairbanks' fascination with the crafts began at a young age. Growing up in a family of artists and craftspeople, he was surrounded by the sights, sounds, and textures of creative expression. This early exposure instilled in him a deep appreciation for the artisanal traditions that would shape his future. As he honed his skills as a painter, sculptor, and printmaker, Fairbanks became increasingly drawn to the world of crafts, recognizing the unique potential of these disciplines to bridge the gap between art and everyday life. Fairbanks' curatorial career, which spanned over three decades, was marked by a series of groundbreaking exhibitions that redefined the boundaries of American crafts. His 1983 exhibition, "The Eloquent Object," showcased the work of 150 craft artists, highlighting the narrative power of functional objects to convey meaning and emotion. This landmark show not only elevated the status of crafts within the art world but also paved the way for future generations of craft artists. Throughout his career, Fairbanks has been an ardent advocate for the importance of craft education. He has taught at numerous institutions, including the Rhode Island School of Design and the Haystack Mountain School of Crafts, inspiring countless students to explore the possibilities of craft as a medium for artistic expression. His commitment to craft education has also led to the development of innovative programs, such as the Fairbanks Center for the Crafts, which provides resources and support for emerging craft artists. Fairbanks' contributions to the American craft movement extend far beyond his own artistic practice and curatorial endeavors. He has served on the boards of prominent craft organizations, including the American Craft Council, and has played a pivotal role in shaping the national conversation around craft policy and advocacy. His tireless efforts have helped to raise the profile of American crafts, both domestically and internationally, and have paved the way for future generations of craft artists to thrive.
content.source_2: It was a chilly winter morning in February 2033 when Jonathan Leo Fairbanks, a renowned American artist and curator, received the prestigious Gold Star medal. The year had already been marked by significant milestones in the art world, and Jonathan's recognition was the culmination of his life's work. As he stood on the podium, surrounded by dignitaries and fellow artists, Jonathan's mind wandered back to the early days of his career. He remembered the countless hours spent honing his craft, the sleepless nights, and the unwavering dedication to his passion. It was a journey that had taken him from the streets of New York City to the galleries of Paris, and finally, to this moment of triumph. The Gold Star medal, awarded by several countries, was a testament to Jonathan's contributions to the world of art. His innovative approach to curation had brought together artists from diverse backgrounds, creating a platform for dialogue and exchange. His own artwork, a fusion of traditional techniques and cutting-edge technology, had inspired a new generation of creatives. As Jonathan accepted the medal, he felt a sense of pride and gratitude. He thought of his mentors, his colleagues, and his family, who had supported him every step of the way. He thought of the countless exhibitions he had organized, the artists he had mentored, and the lives he had touched through his art. The ceremony was a grand affair, with representatives from around the world in attendance. The room was filled with the hum of conversation, the clinking of glasses, and the soft glow of camera flashes. Jonathan's speech was met with applause and tears, as he spoke of the power of art to bring people together, to inspire, and to challenge. In the days that followed, Jonathan's medal was met with widespread acclaim. The art world celebrated his achievement, and his name became synonymous with excellence. The Gold Star medal was more than just a recognition of his work; it was a symbol of the impact he had had on the world. As Jonathan looked out at the city, he knew that this was just the beginning. He had a new platform, a new voice, and a new sense of purpose. He would continue to push the boundaries of art, to challenge the status quo, and to inspire a new generation of creatives. The year 2033 would be remembered as a turning point in Jonathan's career, a moment when his dedication, passion, and creativity were recognized on a global scale.
